title: Sheet 5B
publication_title: James Ensor: The Temptation of Saint Anthony
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">A crowd of fantastical figures and creatures, drawn in black colored pencil, stands below a crescent moon that begins on sheet 4B. The moon is an attribute of the ancient goddess Diana (Artemis in Greek mythology) of Ephesus, who here joins the assembly of mythical and monstrous figures at far right. Rendered partially over preexisting drawing, she extends into sheet 5C. Other mythological references include the Chimera and a sphinx. On the far left, extending from sheet 5A, is a winged, serpentlike figure that resembles a harpy or, possibly, the Persian mythical creature Simorg-Anka (described by Gustave Flaubert in his Temptation of Saint Anthony). Near this figure is a dragon’s head with large, bulging eyes, reminiscent of the grotesque dragon figure in the lower left of Ensor’s 1886 drawing The Devils Dzitts and Hihahox, Commanded by Crazon Riding a Furious Cat, Lead Christ into Hell (fig. 1). Perhaps this creature—as well as the nude with a monster head next to the dragon—belonged to a sketch for the 1886 drawing that Ensor later reworked for The Temptation. Historical restorations are preserved along the bottom edge, and a small, lighter, circular area, formerly patched by the artist, is visible at center right. On the back of this sheet is a study in graphite for Adam and Eve Expelled from Paradise (1887; Royal Museum of Fine Arts, Antwerp).

In this sheet Ensor also referenced depictions by his contemporaries Félicien Rops (see fig. 2), a fellow member of Les XX (Les Vingt, 1883–93), and by the French artists Odilon Redon (see fig. 3, fig. 4, and fig. 5) and Gustave Moreau (see fig. 6). These artists’ imagery merged in the later nineteenth century with scientific explorations of evolution and biology, illustrations for phantasmagoria, and displays of the deformed (see folios 7C/D and 7G/H). The head of one figure is replaced by an animal skull that resembles a fossil or dragon’s head (see sheet 6A). This hybridization of animal and human form alludes to current debates over Charles Darwin’s theories and was often used by caricaturists, especially J. J. Grandville, to parody the bourgeoisie (see fig. 7 and fig. 8). SMC/KJN

fig. 1 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). The Devils Dzitts and Hihahox, Commanded by Crazon Riding a Furious Cat, Lead Christ into Hell, 1886. Pencil and black chalk on paper, glued on panel; 17.3 × 22.7 cm (6 13/16 × 8 15/16 in.). Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels, 7660. © Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels/Photo d’art Speltdoorn & Fils, Bruxelles.

fig. 2 Félicien Rops (Belgian, 1833–1898). The Sphinx, 1895. Unframed heliogravure; image: 29.2 × 21.6 cm (11 1/2 × 8 1/2 in.); overall: 61 × 45.7 cm (24 × 18 in.). Museum of Fine Arts, Ghent. © Lukas—Art in Flanders VZW.

fig. 3 Odilon Redon (French, 1840–1916). The Chimera Gazed at All Things with Fear from Night, 1886. Lithograph in black on ivory China paper collé, laid down on white wove paper; image/chine: 24.9 × 18.4 cm (9 13/16 × 7 1/4 in.); sheet: 45.1 × 31.2 cm (17 3/4 × 12 5/16 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Gift of Elizabeth Hammond Stickney, 1920.1603.

fig. 4 Odilon Redon (French, 1840–1916). Blossoming, 1879. Lithograph on mounted ivory China paper; 33.4 × 25.9 cm (13 3/16 × 10 3/16 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, The Stickney Collection, 1920.1556.

fig. 5 Odilon Redon (French, 1840–1916). Frontispiece from Iwan Gilkin’s Tenebres (Darkness), 1892. Lithograph in black on ivory China paper laid down on ivory wove paper; image/chine: 19.9 × 12.2 cm (7 7/8 × 4 13/16 in.); sheet: 42.9 × 31.4 cm (16 7/8 × 12 3/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, The Stickney Collection, 1920.1706.

fig. 6 Gustave Moreau (French, 1826–1898). La peri, 1865. Graphite, with brush and black ink, gray wash, and touches of gold metallic paint, heightened with traces of white gouache, on cream wove tracing paper, laid down on ivory wove paper; 35.7 × 25.5 cm (14 1/16 × 10 1/16 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Prints and Drawings Department Purchase Fund, 1973.722.

fig. 7 J. J. Grandville (pseud. Jean Ignace Isidore Gérard, French, 1803–1847). Illustration published in Un autre monde (H. Fournier, 1844), p. 198. Note the monster at bottom right.

fig. 8 J. J. Grandville (pseud. Jean Ignace Isidore Gérard, French, 1803–1847). Dancing monkey, published in Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux (Hetzel et Paulin, 1842).
